comments.commentBody: In the old days, I hear, mail delivery came twice a day in Manhattan.

Consider the following:

The postal service provides jobs.
Power outages may occur, but the mail gets delivered regardless.
Too much e-mail clutters up my computer screen and much can be overlooked in the indistinguishable morass.
I use my credit card number on-line as little as possible. Anything can be hacked - take it from someone once in the computer business.
My "important mail" is delivered to my mailbox. Finding that filed paper product is essential and easily done.
Sending packages of a certain size by mail is essential.
Registered mail is a worthwhile service. Signature required can be priceless.
Catalogues can be a pain-in-the neck, but I prefer to have them in hand rather than on the screen. (Love the lay-outs and the color etc.)
The same can be said for magazines and the local newspaper and the NY Times. All are portable and can go with me anywhere.
I clip - especially ads.
I look in my mailbox 5 days a week. Why not. Hand deliverables can happen and are a two-way-street in my town. "I'll leave it in your mailbox."
My Christmas Cards go by mail. I prefer to receive them in a paper format with ....... festive embellishments. Display of same is also festive.
I also do my thank you notes by hand on suitable paper.
Sympathy cards for serious events - death, illness, etc. require ink.
Charitable solicitations depend upon the mails. They realize the request in hand is worth two in the ......... whatever.

There is more, but I hope that you get my drift.
I'm sure eBay is keeping USPS alive too...I use it a lot!

I am very grateful to the US Posatal Service that has done a wonderful job of delivering my mail in rain, sleet, and snow for many years.  But the reality is that most important mail is delivered electronically and paper mail is slowly becoming extinct.   I only look in our mailbox 3 days a week now.  The people who still need good mail service 5 days a week door to door are the elderly, disabled, and some of the poor who do not have computers.  The funding of the postal service should decline and focus primarily on these areas. People like me can do without mail 6 days a week and would be happy with a cluster mailbox. It is time to accept the reality that times are changing and we need to reevaluate all current Federal programs for cost savings.

You are right that Apple's lead designer, Jony Ive, has expressed his admiration for the designs of Braun's designer Dieter Rams. There is no doubt that Ive has been inspired by Rams' work.

Rams returns the favor. As he wrote, "I have always regarded Apple products – and the kind words Jony Ive has said about me and my work – as a compliment. Without doubt there are few companies in the world that genuinely understand and practise the power of good design in their products and their businesses. "

"I am always fascinated when I see the latest Apple products. Apple has managed to achieve what I never achieved: using the power of their products to persuade people to queue to buy them."

Applying principles of design to new products is different from what Samsung does. Braun never made a smartphone or a laptop. Samsung looks at a specific product in a specific market, imitates it, and competes with it directly. Samsung saw the iPhone and copied the overall look, just like Samsung copied Blackberry before the iPhone came out.

Design patents on things like rounded rectangles sound stupid, I agree. But how else can a company describe the features of its products that make it unique? It was the look of the icons, the pinch to zoom, the rubber banding at the end of lists, etc, that Apple patented. These were all features that made the iPhone the iPhone. Companies that followed in Apple's footsteps had a roadmap.

Thor: excellent, thoughtful remarks.

Apple clearly deserves patents

for many excellent design innovations.

But sorry, rounded corners on rectangles

is clearly neither original

nor "innovative and non-obvious".

by any standard....!!!

Is Apple the new Evil Empire Jobs once sought to liberate us from ?

Full disclosure: I'm a fan who owns multiple macbooks, Ipad, Ipod, Apple monitor/keyboard, etc.

@Thor - Copying the basic designs of an original product is still fair practice because the companies still have to compete on the grounds of performance, delivery, and customer satisfaction, all of which Samsung routinely trounces Apple on.

eReaders are all basically the same device, the Kindle, Kobo, and Nook offering very little in differing designs or functionality, indeed all three companies have experimented with certain models to try to distinguish themselves but continually settle back to the designs that work best. This is completely natural especially with technology - all DVD players, VCRs, DVD players, MP3 players, and now smartphones tend to be the same basic, effective design.

Competition comes in the form of performance, durability, customer service, policies, perks, etc. The big problem that Apple has ever had is that design was Steve Jobs one and one true strength. He chose for Apple to follow a patent war strategy because he only cared about protecting his arguably non-patentable designs. The Apple, even under Jobs, ignored the consumer completely figuring they could patent the design and basically lock out anyone from offering a device that was remotely similar.

That's not how innovation or competition is supposed to work. Companies are not supposed to compete on surface level elements alone, if at all. It's the actual services they provide to consumers that maters most.

YOU HAVE GOT TO

BE KIDDING....!!!.

Apple was issued a patent for a rectangle with rounded corners ?

REALLY ???!!!

Patents are only supposed to be granted for ideas

that are both highly innovative and "non-obvious".

This in a nutshell is everything you need to know about what's

totally messed up with our patent system - not to mention Apple...!

As a Verizon customer, I complained to them about their willingness to turn over my call metadata without so much as a whimper. They were gracious enough to call me personally to tell me they could not tell me anything. But here's the rub: small companies want to protect our rights, but have no resources to do so. Companies like Verizon have sufficient legal resources and dollars to stand up for their customers, but refuse to do so.

No one will protect your rights unless you speak up. The companies that have "legally" turned over your private information also have a business to run, and they will only speak up in your favor if their revenue or customer satisfaction is in danger. File a complaint with the BBB against your service provider if you believe your rights and privacy are not being protected. Most providers will respond directly. One voice is rather small, but if a hundred thousand or a million customers complain, these companies will begin to stand up for their customers, as it should be.

We have it within our power to change this intrusion upon our privacy.  It is called a vote.  If your congressman voted for the patriot act, vote against him and for someone who will stand up for freedom.  If you don,t, you deserve what you get and have no right to complain.

This isn't just about small companies fighting for freedom while large companies being too beholden to their shareholders and assets. This is about the next Googles and Facebooks out there being squashed by a totalitarian government before they ever have a chance to develop into big companies. The loss to our society by these unconstitutional searches and seizures include not only our freedoms but our capital. The government is destroying our future national prosperity. Already billions of dollars in business is being lost by American cloud computing companies as customers around the world flee to European and other companies based in freer societies than ours. To those who think that totalitarian surveillance is only something that matters for "wrongdoers," I would ask them to consider whether they would rather live in a wealthy free society or an impoverished totalitarian one? Take a look at North Korea and we see where the US is heading.

Homeless? Been there, done that.

Having struggled with housing issues in what is literally the most expensive rental market in the US, I think the one thing that even Times readers can't really grasp is how many people are "invisibly" homeless.

Your 42-year-old saleswoman at Nordstrom with impeccable make-up? She's been living out of her ex-husband's Range Rover since last year, and she's still more carefully dressed than you are. So you'd never even think.

The 25-year-old bartender preparing your flawless cocktail? Sleeping on a succession of couches since November, and his back is still in better shape than yours. And your personal trainer pieced her "home" together last winter through a series of house-sitting gigs for her wealthy clients.

We don't count as homeless, but our numbers are growing. The rents aren't just "too damn high". For many working people, they're not an option.

This recession has hit those outside the baby boomer generation the hardest. If there's a silver lining to any of this, we've found a deep camaraderie. But something's gotta give. Or maybe this is just the new normal.

I agree with much of your analysis.

My father, who was born in 1921, was fond of saying, especially during the latter half of the 1960s, that what the country needed was another Great Depression. Although I disagreed with him, I understood his motives for saying that.

My question is: if an economic collapse occurred now to the extent that the unemployment rate reached 20%, no mater how much the government tried to tweak how unemployment is counted, would there be a return to compassion in the overall attitude of society, or not?

Or is the problem that many people think 'compassion' should be doled out by NGO's rather than by government? The "thousand points of light" substitute for government programs.

I attribute American callousness toward the poor and the homeless to the following three factors:
(1)Poverty and homelessness are frightening. It is likely that many displace their fear of these conditions into anger and disgust. The precarious state of the economy over the past five years may have increased the fear, anger and disgust with which the poor and homeless are viewed.
(2)Many Americans have no or little meaningful contact with the homeless or the poor, making it easy to view poor or homeless Americans as "the other". This distancing leads to condemnation and distrust.
(3)The "welfare queen" stereotype first popularized by Ronald Reagan has become a staple of conservative belief and has grown pervasive. Contrary to stereotype, most welfare payments are received by whites and welfare recipients are not living lavishly.

America's collective lack of compassion for the homeless serves us poorly and runs contrary to our historic generosity toward those in trouble.

What, prey tell, is the purpose of these sorts of gatherings? You enter a room. Inside that room, and scattered about at various points before entering, are people you once knew in the tender part of youth where everything seem possible and nothing, save world wide nuclear war, seemed horrible or much threatening. Only a few moment's stray thoughts are needed to confirm that none of that applies any longer.

It is that sense of anticipation and limitlessness, combined with youthful energy and endless curiosity, that made those times so wonderful. Well, going to Yale, helped too, I am sure. Going to any good school where there is a surging feeling of intellectual growth and a certainty on the part of the professors that they are not wasting their time is a true privilege. What was lived then can never be relived, only pawed over like a cold and moldering meal.

It can be crushing to compare a young person you once knew with the reality of what happened to them in life, to realize that all that energy and hopefulness came to an end on a rain slicked road or in the steel hard grasp of cancer. It is, on some level, an unacceptable blob of knowledge that locks into the brain and won't let go. It just might be better not to look back, unless that's all you can do.

You're completely wrong about Standard mail. Standard mail subsidizes First Class mail - not the other way around.

Standard mail is delivered to the USPS pre-sorted, pre-paid and bar-coded - eliminating all the most labor-intensive processes.

Without Standard mail, our First Class mail would cost as much as 10x more.

The costs to our economy of eliminating Standard mail - to consumers as well as to all the businesses that rely on Standard mail AND to tax revenues from those businesses - would be enormous.

If you don't want to receive some of type of promotional mail, all you have to do is contact the Direct Marketing Association and sign up for its DMA Choice service to stop the types of mail you don't want. Here's the link:
https://www.dmachoice.org/index.php

And btw, many of us actually DO want to receive catalogs, promotional offers, and mail from charitable causes we support.
Not just the unions, your congressperson and senators have fought it for years, too, irrespective of party.

There is a very simple way to reform the USPS and make it solvent, but the postal workers' union is virulently opposed to it. The solution is to dramatically increase postage rates for standard, aka junk, mail.

How would this work? Standard mail, which is the least profitable line of business the USPS in engaged in, accounts for a large percentage of mail volume and USPS revenue, but a much larger percentage of USPS labor costs. Standard mail is also something that USPS' customers not only do not want, but most customers dislike standard mail and consider it a public nuisance. And standard mail is a complete, unmitigated disaster for the environment.

If standard mail volumes were greatly reduced, the USPS would need far fewer mail processing facilities and far fewer employees at those facilities, allowing a significant reduction in labor costs. Furthermore, the concept of the USPS as a public good would actually become true again, as the mail would no longer serve as a mechanism to disseminate unwanted advertising.

Let's stop being completely irresponsible in wasting taxpayer dollars to inundate the public with millions of tons of unwanted trash. Standard mail should be rare and expensive, not a ubiquitous stream of refuse.

Very true. I worked as an attorney in a large white shoe firm and eventually opted out. I did well, but the work wasnt very interesting. I never identified well with the role, never felt it actually warranted the respect people assigned it, and realized, the moment they handed me that stack of business cards, how little that variety of "respect" really mattered to me. I also grew up without money, and never related to the aspirational talk around me (joining that country club, planning on that McMansion or that house in Nantucket, coveting a partners new 70k car) . A colleague, who grew up with a professional mom, with a high-end lifestyle, talked about moving into a lower paying, family friendly career, or quitting entirely. I think she was just as unhappy as I was, but she had different ideas about who she was and what she wanted. She stayed in, and I suspect she is happy with her choice in a way that I could not be.

I don't know where these attitudes originate, but I do think that when women do have choices, our gut feelings have a lot to say about where we end up.
